TitleMain.Title: Recht op goede gezondheidszorg : wegwijzer voor patiÃ«nten, studenten en professionals
Small pox : the secret killer
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / [presented by] Filmakers Library, Inc. ; produced by Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This documentary details the history of smallpox, its near elimination, and current dilemmas. Dispite having signed an international agreement, the Soviets developed the smallpox virus for potential military use. They considered it a weapon of last resort because of its lethal and unstoppable nature. After the Soviet Union's collapse, smallpox stock may have found its way into the hands of rogue states or terrorists.

TitleMain.Title: Update on the state and local preparedness grant program
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / produced by the Public Health Training Network, Division of Professional Development and Evaluation, Public Health Practice Program Office, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ; produced for the Public Health Training Network, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Atlanta, Ga.] : Centers for Disease Control & Prevention, [2002?]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This program, targeted to state health officers, epidemiologists, public health and emergency management leaders, public health professionals, and others, presents the status of CDC's Supplemental Funding for Public Health Preparedness and Response for Bioterrorism Program. Outlines the benchmarks identified by HHS for critical preparedness and the focus areas they are a part of when dealing with bioterrorism, other emerging infections, and other public health threats and emergencies. A question and answer session concludes each presentation.

Tape 2 (60 minutes): Focus Area F: Risk communication and health information dissemination -- Focus Area G: Education and training -- Conclusion.

TitleMain.Title: OSHA inspections, citations, and penalties

Abstract.AbstractText: One of the primary missions of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is to enforce standards by performing inspections and issuing citations for violations. OSHA performs both programmed and unprogrammed inspections to accomplish this goal. Programmed inspections are completed in high-hazard industries and for specific National and Special Emphasis Programs. Unprogrammed inspections include (in order of priority) imminent danger, fatality/ catastrophe, and complaint/referral investigations. Compliance safety and health officers perform both programmed and unprogrammed inspections following a three-step process: opening conference, walkabout, and closing conference. Healthcare facilities should be aware of their right to require a warrant for an inspection. Decisions on whether to request a warrant, how to limit the scope of an inspection, and who will be involved in an inspection should become policy and be reviewed by legal council. The process to appeal citations and penalties and petition for modifying an abatement should also be familiar to the healthcare facility. It is clear that the newly reorganized OSHA, with its emphasis on partnerships and the new small business office, is focusing on collaborative efforts rather than taking more punitive measures. Therefore, to limit violations as much as possible, healthcare facilities are encouraged to use the tools and outreach available through OSHA and overlapping agencies, such as the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.

OtherSubject.OtherSubjectName: United States. Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

TitleMain.Title: Child support reforms in PRWORA : initial impacts

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Discussion papers (Assessing the New Federalism (Program)) ; no. 02-02

Abstract.AbstractText: Child support reforms were an integral part of the 1996 welfare reform law. By strengthening child support enforcement, Congress intended to increase child support collections and thus improve the self-sufficiency of low-income families. This paper assesses whether the child support reforms enacted in 1996 improved child support outcomes during the initial years after enacting welfare reform. It uses a difference-in-difference-in-difference approach with data from the 1997 and 1999 National Survey of America's Families. We find that some of the key child support reforms, most notably new hire directories and improved paternity establishment procedures, have contributed to gains in child support outcomes among low- and middle-income children with a never-married mother, a group that has received little child support in the past.

Abstract.AbstractText: The National Fire Protection Association Life Safety CodeÂ® describes design elements and equipment needed to prevent, detect, respond to, and escape from fires and similar emergencies that can occur in healthcare facilities. Environmental health, safety, and security managers should be familiar with the systems in their facility and how these systems operate to protect occupants, and these managers must be able to ensure the systems function in an emergency. This analysis describes some of the common features of life safety systems found in many hospitals and the requirements for maintaining and testing these systems.

TitleMain.Title: Hospital preparedness for bioterrorism

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Secaucus, N.J. : Network for Continuing Medical Education, c2002.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Is the American medical community ready for a mass-casualty event on its home turf? In the wake of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, and following the subsequent uncontrolled spread of anthrax through the U.S. postal system, many consider this to be a timely question. Public health and disaster management experts have been preparing for the possibility of terrorism and bioterrorism for years, however, and procedures and systems are in place that enable hospitals and clinicians to cope with potential disaster. In this video program, two New York-based emergency physicians with expertise in prehospital care, diaster management, and infectous diseases share their perspectives on the current status of preparedness in American health care facilities. They also describe how you and your hospital can sharpen response skills to ensure high-quality care without compromising safety, and they provide the latest clinical information about dealing with biological and chemical agents.

TitleMain.Title: Electrical power distribution management

Abstract.AbstractText: An electrical power distribution management program (EPDMP) should be an integral part of a healthcare facility's utilities management plan. The EPDMP must comply with the requirements of the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations Environment of Care standards and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standards-NFPA 99, Health Care Facilities Handbook; NFPA 70, the National Electrical CodeÂ®; and NFPA 110, Standard for Emergency and Standby Power Systems. The EPDMP must adequately address all performance, maintenance, and testing requirements of the normal, essential, nonessential, and emergency electrical power supply and distribution systems while providing for reliable electrical power and a patient care environment that is reasonably safe from shock and burn hazards associated with the use of electric appliances, as defined in NFPA 99-1999 12-2, 12-2.5.

TitleMain.Title: The Hospital Emergency Incident Command System

Abstract.AbstractText: The Hospital Emergency Incident Command System (HEICS) is a standardized incident management program adapted from the nationally used Incident Command System. HEICS is flexible for use in all sizes and types of emergencies. HEICS assigns responsibility during an emergency, identifies and standardizes all key responsibilities and actions, establishes clear reporting channels, and uses a common nomenclature that facilitates multiagency response.

TitleMain.Title: The scope and impact of welfare reform's immigrant provisions

Abstract.AbstractText: The 1996 Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act (PRWORA) not only overhauled the nation's welfare system, it redefined immigrants' access to public benefits. Indeed the law's immigrant provision--to which an entire title is dedicated (Title IV)--can be viewed as a watershed in the related domains of immigrant integration and immigration policy, as well as the federalism issues the new provisions raise. In this paper, we discuss the background and character of the changes introduced by this comprehensive, far-reaching law and then sketch the post-enactment responses of the Congress, the states, and the courts. We further explore the impacts that the law has had on benefit use among immigrants, highlighting the changes in usage among different immigrant groups and factors related to these changes, such as naturalization and rising incomes. We conclude by discussing a number of issues that may be examined within the context of welfare reauthorization.

TitleMain.Title: Bioterrorism for healthcare : essential disaster planning

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 1 videocassette (13 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in. + 1 guide (9 p.)

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This video shows the basics of detecting a BT outbreak. Signs include an influx of otherwise healthy people with serious disease, diseases that rapidly worsen, and unusual symptoms (e.g., flu-like symptoms without runny noses.) Viewers learn what precautions to take with these diseases. Many BT diseases, such as botulism and anthrax, only require standard precautions. Smallpox is the most dangerous requiring airborne precautions. Biological weapons are frightening. An actual or hoax BT incident could cause an anxious community to overwhelm healthcare facilities. All healthcare providers, not just ED staff and physicians, play a major role in reducing public anxiety.

TitleMain.Title: Homeland security (HLS) : protecting our public's health
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [electronic resource] / NIH Information Technology Acquisition and Assessment Center (NITAAC).

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: (CIT): An all-day symposium sponsored by the NIH Information Technology Acquisition and Assessment Center (NITAAC), begins an innovative, informative and useful educational series of meetings focused on encouraging government agencies to use the latest technology and work together to combat terrorism. As a result of the terrorist attacks on America, Homeland Security (HLS) issues have become a top priority for all federal, state, and local government agencies. Bioterrorism preparedness rests in large part on the ability of the public health establishment to perform and protect. The NIH HLS Symposium will help Government officials learn how to improve our nation's surveillance network by sharing information and resources through state-of-the-art computer systems, and incorporating more cutting edge IT equipment and services to detect and prevent terrorist attack.

TitleMain.Title: Kennewick Man : an epic drama of the West
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / a Riverside Films production ; a film by Kyle Carver and Ryan Purcell.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: New York, N.Y. : Filmakers Library, c2001.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: When a human skull was found by the Columbia River near Kennewick, Washington in 1996, it turned out to be one of the oldest and most complete skeletons ever found in North America, igniting a firestorm of controversy pitting scientists against Native Americans. The scientists demanded the right to study the bones, while the Umatilla Tribe believed the bones to be sacred and ancestral. When the American government ruled the bones would be repatriated, eight scientists then filed a lawsuit in order to block the action. This documentary explores the cultural assumptions and differing opinions among the various groups involved, looks at the far-reaching implications for the future of anthropology and present-day relations between Native and non-native people.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Commentary: James Chatters, Dave Deacy, Roger Downey, Francis McManamon, Dutch Meyer, Will Thomas, Bernie Whitebear.

TitleMain.Title: Dr. Bern. Schwetz all hands

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (60 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Duplication copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (Betacam SP) (60 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (60 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Dr. Bernard Schwetz presides over this meeting of FDA employees on September 17, 2001 following the September 11, 2001 attack on the United States. Many FDA security personnel discuss the measures being implemented to secure the building and the employees. A question and answer session followed the presentations.
